DISCUSSING ARIZONA LAW
Refusina MuiI

NEW ORLEANS = (ANPD In
letter sent to, and made public by
both local daily newspaper (New
Orleans States Item) and tele-
vision station (MDSU-TV) a white
couple, DR.. and Mrs. M. Miller
have urged an end to the Louisi-
ana grants-in-aid program which
is currently used to make itpos-
sible for white children to attend
segregated schools. Declaring
that the grant-in-aid program has
been subject to many complaints
of misuse and abuse of funds, the
letter asserted, Louisiana has a
responsibility to provide its
children the best in public educa-
ton. Let's meet this RESPONSE
bility."

COUPLE URGES
ENDING WHITE
PUPIL AID

Troubles in Southeast Asia continue plague the United States
supplies reaching
strategic points unable full strength because
of advisory aides.


unlikely forces fighting against the side
assisting they little because
of unlimited supply of men.


Before the year begins careful planning and
the United States is let of our
soldiers advisory would be off
withdraw all support.


The made much of impression
forget that all lives precious even
calling action advisory
missions


There predicted Vetnam surround
ing of Red China be overlooked
should ounder policies the constant
of turmoil in the southeastern part of the world

VIEWS, PREvIEWs
AND REVIEWS


Edward Bonks
Our Southeast Woes

The four boys and a girl were
born to Mrs. Felisberto Mutan-
qua, wife of an African farmer
who lives near the port of In
hambane.
AFRICAN CUNTS IMPROVING STEADILY

Twas TOUR Gays before LIZ ISL
mas and all through the Bankses
house was confusion. No, we we're
not in a state of utter confusion,
nor was it bedlam. We we're pre-
pairing for our long awaited trip
to Europe, while finishing the
Christmas edition and making
last minute plans.


For the past three weeks, my
spouse has been battling his bron-
chial condition. When he i'm
proved--it seems as though my
white corpuscles decided to let
down their guard. Every mag
Unable allergen present came
near and invaded my body.


had been inwardly pleased
with my excellent summer. l
had been bothered less with the
allergies than in any time past.
This was partly due to the new
year round air conditioning which
we had installed.


Within the past two weeks while.
rushing and making harried trips
to shop, to the printer, to the
bakery and to the cleaners, |
developed rash on my hands.


Quickly soothed it with some
ointment prescribed by our ply
stefan. This eaSed the condition
and l was hopeful that my hands
would be clear before we de-
parted.


Alas, when JOY comes watch
out for sorrow One night had
a terrific breathing episode and
l managed to get immediate re-
lief.


Three days ago the allergy bug
struck again. This time the fumes
from roofing job attacked my
respiratory organs and within
three hours | was almost speech
less.


For two days I used sign Ian
qua ge, wrote notes and whispered
in a deep bass. My husband said
he liked the peace but he missed
my dulcet tones. After several
bright yellow capsules and a nose
spray, l resumed my good voice
and now l am pushed trying to
wind up another week paper with
my husband s help. We are doing
three things at once.


We have our bags open all over
the house, we put in various ar
ticles from time to time. We find
copy for the next editions, we
make notes for those kind souls
who will publish the paper while
we are away.


Sunday was a not so typical
day. We arose early and the &C
tivity started with the usual fruit
Juice, cereal and tea. My hus-
band was reading the mornings
paper when he decided we should
choose and pack some items
we would want.


Between the telephone calls,
visits, radio programs, reading
papers, tipping notes, addressing
cards, emptying trash, making
lunch, shining shoes and washing
clothes - l barely managed to
drop into bed an hour after mid
night.


Wednesday, Dec. %, our date
of departure seems close--how-
ever, from the number Of things
we must do surely it's more
than two days away.

Sights und Sounds
EIoise Bunks
Making Haste

LISBON, Portugal Africa's
quintuplets, born prematurely in
mozambique a ninth ago, left


their incubators and their par
ents soon will take them home.

Though 1t is not an original HOught--He
publishers and editors Of The Arizona Tribune
extend best 1Oishes Of the season to all OF our
readers, advertisers and carriers. We hope
that this Yuletide 1Oill be the WeYY7eSt one
YOU haze ever exbe Y1enced.


The sbi11t of Christmas Wiu echo through
the city, through the state and the ent1Te
nation We should remember TO maze open
hearts and open minds all during the year,
not only at this season.


Help make this Christmas more JOYFUL by
giving just a small gift. The most inexpensive
gift Of all is saying "MeT7y Christmas.


AS ne celebrate our holiday in England, our
thoughts 10il keep the seasons cheer IN Phoe-
mix. too.
GREETINGS TO ALL

Announcement of a Sbe eta cuLaY southwest
e1n COME renee on the problems of the poverty
stricken was made and a cOnside ruble amount
of money wiH be used to support 1T.


Half or more of several thousands Of dol
lars Will be disbuYSed IN transportation and
lodging expenses. There WiH be many persons
attending the conference and many meetings
wiH be held. Findings Of this gigantic con-
ference, hailed by its chairman, Robert
Choate, wil be used to binbOint and discover
areas where the antibOUe7ty program can be
utilized.


appears that many cities and states haze
already had endless surveys. Many c0mnatu-
ity agencies haze files and files Of infoY11d-
tion. We haze more Information gathered by
ne lfaYe units of our municipal, state and fed
e1ul organizations.


Is there need to taste thousands Of dol
lars on a regional COME renee Uhen the anti
poverty programs must in the end be aug
mented ON a state or city basis


The problems of ca oh area 1Oit]1in the
southwest are too diverse and of such mag
nitude that this conference Wiu probably
dissOlUe as another glorious attempt TO Ie0d
the Negroes, the Indians and the MexiCan--
Amer cans into more similar activities IN
the future.


Those thousands of dollars which Wiu be
spent at the conference could be more Uisely
used to feed, clothe, shelter or educate some
of those the conference uiH study and discuss.
